Give them your support, have a go and see what you think and don't judge it as one of the many abandoned rip offs that are found on Steam. It is free and developed by volunteers who are sticking to their task over many years - review the game as such. It is as strong as the community behind it.

I reported a problem, it was fixed the same day. The game is playable although the UI is a little clunky, but you can build a fully functioning Roman city and it looks the part too. The good news? It's only going to get better because it is open source and that means community development.

I have played and beaten Caesar III many, many times. At this game's current state in early, it is buggy and essentially unplayable. Assets are either ripped straight from Caesar III, or are very shoddily made. Additionally, basic functions that were bugged but still manageable in Caesar III (such as pathing of prefects resulting in fires even when an area should be protected) are completely unmanageable in this version, to the extent that a city of 300 needs three fully employed, fully stocked markets in order to fulfill citizen's needs.

Overall I enjoy this idea, and was a huge fan of Caesar III, but I would have much rather seen a new, very similar game rather than a carbon copy where the pen wasn't pushed down quite hard enough.
